item.title: Rumor: Next Batman Game Could Be Coming to PS6
item.description:
Summary

  • Rocksteady's next Batman game may get a PlayStation 6 release, running on next-gen hardware.
  • Job postings hint at another Batman title with mechanics from the Arkham series.
  • The next Batman game's development aligns with the PlayStation 6's rumored launch in 2027.

Rocksteady Studios' rumored Batman game may get a PlayStation 6 release, according to a recent job posting at the company. The Arkham series is one of the most beloved superhero video game franchises to date, so hopes are high for the next entry, even if the recent spin-off Suicide Squad: Kill the Justice League largely fell flat. Whenever it does come out, Rocksteady's next Batman game could have the advantage of running on next-gen hardware.

A recent job posting led some to believe Rocksteady is working on another Batman title, as the description mentioned several mechanics and features central to the Arkham series. While the studio has yet to formally announce such a project, it's looking increasingly likely that it does have something similar in the works. Another open position fans have spotted pushes these rumors even further by hinting at the possibility of a PS6 release.

Warner Bros. Discovery recently posted a job listing for a Senior Core Engine Programmer at Rocksteady Studios. According to the job description, the Programmer will be working on an unannounced AAA title, and while that doesn't explicitly say it's a Batman game, the Arkham universe is the most obvious candidate for such a game. More intriguingly, it also mentions "the next generation of consoles" as part of the title's target hardware. It won't be solely next-gen, though, as it also mentions the PS5 and Xbox Series X, the latter of which contradicts a previous rumor that Rocksteady's next Batman game would be a PlayStation exclusive.

Rocksteady Job Listing Suggests Next Batman Game Could Come to Next-Gen Consoles

The PlayStation 6 and next Xbox consoles may take a while to come out, but it's likely the same story for this Rocksteady game. Hiring has just started, and it hasn't been long since the studio's last release, so its next project is likely in its very early stages. Some rumors suggest the PlayStation 6 could launch by the end of 2027, too, which would not be too long a wait. Even if it takes longer, though, the timeline still works out for this unannounced game, whether it's a Batman title or not, to get a PS6 release, considering how long AAA dev cycles can be.

Rocksteady's next Batman game isn't the first title to be rumored to come to the PlayStation 6. A different job listing hinted that a Horizon spin-off could skip the PS5 to go straight to the PS6. Without any word from Sony on the console, though, it's unclear if and when any of these games will truly be PS6 titles.

item.title: Assassin's Creed Shadows: Stolen Faith Quest Walkthrough
item.description:
After forming an alliance with Kyonyo in Assassin's Creed Shadows , he sends off Naoe to look for his old warrior friend, Mitsumune, who's camped at Nunobiki falls in the Stolen Faith quest. However, convincing Mitsumune to join the fight will take some extra work as he requests Naoe to retrieve a statue for him that was stolen by bandits. So, the Stolen Faith quest will prove to be vital for Naoe in strengthening her allies before confronting Wada Koretake.

Where to Find Mitsumune in Stolen Faith Quest in Assassin's Creed Shadows

Players can find Mitsumune north of Amagasaki town up the trail leading to the Nunobiki Falls in the Stolen Faith quest of Assassin's Creed Shadows . Players should ride their horse/mount up the trail and use the Pathfinder feature to avoid getting off-track. After following the twisting and winding trails of Nakayama Peak, you'll stumble upon a camp with Mitsumune near the waterfall.

After talking to Mitsumune, he'll request Naoe to retrieve the statue of Shinran for him that was stolen by bandits. Only after bringing the statue to him will he join the cause and help in the fight against Wada Koretake.

Location of Toneyama Post Town & The Statue of Shinran in Stolen Faith Quest

To retrieve the Shinran statue for Mitsumune in the Stolen Faith quest, players will need to head east, through the Senri Hills, to reach the Toneyama Post Town in AC Shadows . After arriving at the location marked on the map above, you'll find yourself at the entrance to this hostile town that's crowded with enemies.

Although players can go inside swinging their sword at every enemy they see, the best approach here is to stealth assassinate as many enemies as you can first. While sticking to the rooftops, go further into the town and use Naoe's Eagle Vision ability to scan the area for any blue/objective dot.

Players will find the statue inside a small room toward the end of Toneyama Post Town . However, the room is guarded by several soldiers, including a large brute. After taking the enemies down, players will be able to pick up the Statue of Shinran.

Taking the Statue of Shinran Back to Mitsumune

After returning to Mitsumune, Naoe will hand over the statue to him . Although he'll be pleased with it, he'll be uncertain if his remaining men will be comfortable laying down their lives once again to go against Wada Koretake.

There's a dialog choice for Naoe when Mitsumune asks her if she's ready for the task. Players can either choose " I am Ready " or " I'm Uncertain ," as both will have the same outcome. After the conversation with Mitsumune, he'll become an ally in the fight against Wada Koretake, marking the Stolen Faith quest in Assassin's Creed Shadows as complete.

item.title: How Assassin's Creed Shadows Establishes the Brotherhood's History in Japan
item.description:
For years, the story of the Japanese Brotherhood of Assassins was very much a mystery. Even though players knew of its existence, there was never a mainline game that really delved into its lore. Luckily, Assassin's Creed Shadows has arrived to finally deliver on that tale. Not only does it finally bring the franchise to the long-awaited setting of Japan, but it also sheds light on exactly what went down for this chapter of the Brotherhood.

From the second Assassin's Creed Shadows starts, players are thrust into the shoes of future assassin, Naoe. They get to watch as the Brotherhood is vanquished, help rebuild it to its former glory, and discover the events that led up to both throughout their adventure. While not every detail has been revealed, the story that Assassin's Creed Shadows tells is a fascinating one. And through post-launch content, the Brotherhood's journey through Japan will likely only get more expansive.

The Japanese Brotherhood Has an Extremely Interesting Story to Tell

The Japanese Brotherhood is Devastated by the Time of AC Shadows

Before Assassin's Creed Shadows , Naoe's mother, Tsuyu, was tasked with establishing a brand-new Brotherhood in Japan alongside other assassins. They ended up succeeding, and the Japanese Brotherhood prospered across the continent, with one of their main goals being to protect the three Imperial Regalia. However, they were eventually hunted down by a mysterious group of samurai known as the Shinbakufu. These samurai ended up massacring the assassins, leaving only three alive and taking two of the Regalia. The survivors fled with the final piece, hoping to keep it from their enemy.

By the time Assassin's Creed Shadows kicks off, the Brotherhood has dwindled even further, with only Naoe's father Nagato and Sandayu being surviving members of the original team. However, they too quickly meet their end at the hands of Oda Nobunga and his army. Nagato is struck down at the start of the game while protagonist Naoe is left for dead. As players push further into the game, they also discover that Yasuke killed Sandayu, leaving the entire Brotherhood decimated.

It is Up to Naoe and Yasuke to Rebuild What Was Lost

In his dying breath, Nagato tells Naoe to follow the blade. So, once she recovers from her wounds, she makes it her mission to avenge his death. As she does so, she also begins to build her own version of the Assassin's Brotherhood. She spends much of her time constructing a Hideout for them to call home, and many of the allies she encounters end up joining her fight. As she continues to take out members of the Shinbakufu, even Yasuke ends up joining her team,

Together, they work to rid the world of evil while also rebuilding much of what was lost. This is the primary focus of the rest of Assassin's Creed Shadow s' story, which makes for a pretty intriguing tale. While other Assassin's Creed games have also had players rebuild a destroyed Brotherhood, this type of story has not really been told for a little while now. Instead, players have either not really played as an Assassin or have worked within a pretty well-built Brotherhood, so this is an exciting change of pace.

Since more content is coming to Assassin's Creed Shadows , there are likely even more stories surrounding this Brotherhood waiting to be told. Players still do not really know what its early days looked like, and Ubisoft has barely scratched the surface of some of the surviving members' stories, so he future is very much unwritten. But for now, players will just have to wait and see where Naoe and Yasuke's journey takes them next.

item.title: 2 Classic PSP Games Are Jumping Ship to the Nintendo Switch
item.description:
Summary

  • Patapon 1+2 Replay, a remastered collection of the first two games, is coming to Nintendo Switch, PS5, and PC on July 17, 2025.
  • Japanese publisher Bandai Namco Entertainment is developing Patapon 1+2 Replay, and has integrated new accessibility features into the collection.
  • The third series entry has not been included in Patapon 1+2 Replay.

Two of the PSP's most beloved rhythm games are making their way to the Nintendo Switch this year. These are none other than the first two Patapon games, and interestingly, this is the fourth PlayStation-owned IP to have officially been announced for a Switch release.

Originally released in 2007, Patapon was developed by Pyramid and the now-defunct PlayStation first-party team Japan Studio. Patapon quickly became a hit among PSP players thanks to its innovative gameplay mechanics, where players control an army of tiny, one-eyed warriors using drum beats. The success of the first Patapon game led to an award-winning sequel in 2008, and then a third entry in 2011. Patapon and Patapon 2 were ported to the PS4 by 2020, and the niche franchise remains a PlayStation cult classic to this day.

Fans of the series have had an eventful year so far, as Patapon 3 was added to the PlayStation Plus Premium classics catalog last month, making the entire trilogy playable on modern hardware. Now, Patapon is making its first-ever debut on the Switch, with the latest Nintendo Direct having announced Patapon 1+2 Replay . Despite it being a Sony-owned IP, PlayStation isn't handling the development of this Patapon collection; Bandai Namco Entertainment is in charge. Patapon 1+2 Replay hits Nintendo Switch, PS5, and PC on July 17, 2025 , and will feature the same beloved gameplay that made the series popular in the first place.

Patapon 1+2 Replay Release Date and New Features

  • July 17, 2025
  • Coming to Nintendo Switch, PS5, and PC

New Features

  • Difficulty settings: Easy, Normal, Hard
  • Adjust timing of button press
  • Keep drum icon displayed at all times

Additionally, Bandai Namco has implemented some new accessibility features in Patapon 1+2 Replay , such as difficulty settings (Easy, Normal, Hard), the ability to adjust button press timing, and keeping the drum icon displayed at all times. Pre-orders for Patapon 1+2 Replay are expected to go live soon, but details around pricing remain under wraps for now. The exclusion of Patapon 3 from this remastered collection is a bit odd, but Sony may be gauging the response to the first two games from Switch users to decide whether to bring the threequel forward as well, possibly in a standalone capacity. Interestingly, Patapon 1+2 Replay wasn't the only legacy PlayStation IP to show up during the March 2025 Nintendo Direct.

Everybody's Golf: Hot Shots , a brand-new entry in the Everybody's Golf franchise developed under the Bandai Namco umbrella, has also been confirmed to launch on Switch, PS5, and PC later this year. Moreover, the Japanese publisher released a remaster of the obscure PS Vita first-party title Freedom Wars in January 2025, and prior to this, PlayStation itself launched LEGO Horizon Adventures on Switch last November. It's clear that Sony is looking to introduce its IPs to the Nintendo audience, and it should be interesting to see how far the gaming giant is willing to go with this multiplatform venture.

item.title: 7 Best Games That Let Players Break The Rules
item.description:
Summary

  • Path of Exile's legacy items break balance, creating godlike builds with infinite stats.
  • Warframe lets players craft unbalanced abilities for unstoppable forces and extreme speed.
  • Super Mario Maker allows inventive level design, defying traditional Mario logic for chaotic creativity.

Some games challenge players to master their mechanics, while others hand over the tools to completely dismantle them. Whether through intentional design or overlooked exploits, certain titles become playgrounds for creative rule-breaking. From games where words reshape reality, to those where alchemy turns characters into near-immortal beings, these games are all the better for bending — or outright breaking — their own systems.

In some cases, developers embrace these quirks. In others, players work tirelessly to uncover ways to push the game's rules far beyond what was ever intended. Here are some of the best games where pushing mechanics to the breaking point is just as fun as playing by the rules.

7 Path of Exile

Legacy Items Retain Overpowered Stats

Path of Exile thrives on customization, but in the Standard League, legacy items turn balance on its head. These relics from past updates retain absurdly overpowered stats, letting players create builds that obliterate the game’s intended challenge. Items like the legacy Vinktar flask grant instant life leech, making characters almost unkillable. Gear items like Kaom’s Heart stack enormous health pools with high-damage bow skills.

Some builds take this rule-breaking further, reaching ridiculous levels of energy shield regeneration or armor values in the billions, effectively making death a non-factor. While these mechanics offer a power trip for veteran players, they also highlight the game’s evolving balance issues. The existence of such broken builds in Standard League creates a fascinating paradox, allowing players to wield godlike strength while reminding them that the game was never designed to be this easy.

6 Warframe

Abilities Scale Infinitely

Warframe is all about bending the rules, giving players the freedom to craft builds that defy the game’s intended balance. Some Warframes boast abilities with infinite damage scaling, effortlessly cutting down high-level enemies. Xaku’s "Grasp of Lohk" steals enemy weapons and turns them against them, while "Gaze" shreds defenses, making even the toughest foes crumble. Then there’s speed. Gauss and Volt, when modded the right way, can reach movement speeds so extreme they rival the game’s own flight systems.

Plus, players have cracked the code for invincibility. By stacking defensive mods like "Adaptation" and leveraging healing or damage-reduction abilities, certain builds turn Warframes into near-unstoppable forces. This level of customization has cemented the game's status as a fan-favorite. Creativity is rewarded with power, and breaking the game’s limits is almost encouraged.

5 Super Mario Maker

Design Levels That Ignore Traditional Mario Logic

Super Mario Maker throws the rulebook out the window, letting players twist classic Mario logic into something all their own. Unlike traditional Mario titles with carefully curated levels, this game hands over the reins, allowing for creations that range from mind-bending complexity to hilarious chaos. Autoplay levels turn players into mere spectators, as Mario glides across the screen with zero input.

Meanwhile, impossible jumps, enemy spam, and brutal Kaizo-style gauntlets push the limits of what the platforming genre can handle. Some levels feel like puzzles, others like endurance tests. A few exist purely to troll unsuspecting players. The game's thriving online community continuously churns out inventive, rule-breaking stages, proving that Super Mario isn’t just about jumping from left to right. Sometimes, it’s about recreating the entire platforming experience, ensuring that no two levels, or playthroughs, are ever the same.

4 ​Baba Is You

Words Change Gameplay Rules, Creating Limitless Puzzle Solutions

Few puzzle games redefine the genre quite like Baba Is You . This mind-bending indie hit lets players rewrite the game's rules by rearranging word tiles, altering interactions and redefining objects on the fly. One moment, Baba is the protagonist; the next, a simple phrase swap turns a rock or even a wall into a controllable character.

The sheer freedom of this mechanic transforms each puzzle into a playground of logic-defying experimentation. Every new word added to the mix deepens the strategic possibilities, making even the simplest sentences game-changing. This dynamic, rule-breaking gameplay has earned Baba Is You widespread acclaim, cementing its place as one of the most innovative puzzle experiences in recent years. Bending the rules isn’t just encouraged, but required.

3 The Elder Scrolls 3: Morrowind

Infinite Alchemy & Magic Stacking Breaks Game Balance

The Elder Scrolls 3: Morrowind is a playground for those who love manipulating the rules. Its intricate alchemy and magic systems practically invite players to break the game in hilarious and overpowered ways. For instance, by stacking Fortify Intelligence potions, intelligence can skyrocket into absurd numbers.

The spell-making system is equally susceptible, allowing for broken spells that cost zero magicka or effects that last indefinitely using the infamous "Soul Trap" glitch. With enough experimentation, players can jump across the entire map, become invincible, or obliterate enemies with reality-warping spells. Rather than feeling like flaws, these exploits have become a beloved part of Morrowind’s identity, embraced by fans for the freedom they provide.

2 Vampire Survivors

Stacked Builds Turn Relentless Survival Into Effortless Destruction

The right build in Vampire Survivors can tip the scales, transforming a desperate struggle into an unstoppable power trip. This roguelike shoot ‘em up exploded in popularity for its deceptively simple gameplay: players maneuver an auto-attacking character through relentless waves of enemies, collecting upgrades and evolving weapons. But the real magic lies in bending the game’s difficulty to absurd extremes.

By stacking the right weapons, passive items, and arcanas, players can achieve near-invincibility, wiping out enemies before they even appear on the screen. Combinations like Soul Eater and Bloody Tear, enhanced with double healing, allow for relentless regeneration, making survival effortless. Some builds unleash such overwhelming firepower that the screen becomes a flashing storm of destruction. These overpowered setups let players break the game’s balance, turning a brutal survival experience into unstoppable carnage.

1 The Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion

The Chameleon Enchantment Grants Permanent Invisibility

The Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion' s sprawling world is filled with danger, but players who exploit the 100% Chameleon effect can waltz through Cyrodiil like a ghost. By stacking enchantments, they become permanently invisible, breaking the game's fundamental mechanics. Unlike the standard Invisibility spell, which shatters upon action, Chameleon lets players steal, attack, and complete quests without consequence. Guards turn a blind eye, enemies swing at empty air, and entire encounters become trivial.

While some see this as a game-breaking oversight, others revel in the freedom it provides, bending the rules of Bethesda’s beloved RPG in absurd ways. Whether it ruins the challenge or enhances the power fantasy depends on the player’s perspective. Still, there's no denying that this exploit embodies Oblivion’s signature open-ended design.
